heading: cisco profit rises 33 percent
subheading: the world's biggest data networking gearmaker reports another big rise in quarterly earnings. icing on the cake: a 2-for-1 stock split.
author: reuters
text: cisco systems, the largest maker of computer networking equipment, on tuesday reported third-quarter profits that rose 33 percent -- in line with forecasts -- and announced a 2-for-1 stock split. the company said net income rose to us$646 million, or 38 cents a share, compared with pro forma net income of $484 million, or 30 cents a share, a year ago. analysts had forecast 37 cents a share, according to first call.revenue rose 44 percent to $3.15 billion from $2.18 billion, helped by strong sales across most product lines."overall, we are very pleased with our [third-quarter] results," said john chambers, cisco's chief executive, in a conference call with analysts.cisco (csco), along with lucent technologies, northern telecom, and others, are racing to provide gear to telephone companies and others that will deliver voice, data, and video over one network using internet technology.chambers said that since the last conference call three months ago, the competitive landscape had not changed appreciably. telecommunications equipment companies continue to buy data networking companies to move into next-generation networks.chambers hasn't changed his thinking on the wisdom of that strategy. "we still believe the majority of these acquisitions will not be successful," chambers said.cisco reported the results after the close of us trading. in regular trading on the nasdaq, cisco rose $2.63 to $111.88. after the market close, cisco climbed another $1.63 to $113.50.cisco set a two-for-one stock split, payable 21 june to shareholders of record on 24 may. it is the eighth time the company has split its stock since cisco first sold shares to the public in february 1990.copyright
